Patricia Cheneau returned to her 9th Ward home in New Orleans shortly after Katrina.
She got help from volunteers to rebuild.
They gutted the place.
When she saw the result, she was heartbroken all over again.
Every window, every doorway, everything has cypress around it.
All that was gone.
I can't replace that, any of that.

Now she has a job overseeing a more mindful approach to removal.
This home in the Esplanade Ridge neighborhood is being dismantled by hand in order to salvage as much material as possible for reuse.
Clipboard in hand, Cheneau logs hours and documents the spoil.

To see somebody take the time to go through these houses and take things apart board by board, and say, hey, this can be used somewhere else, is much more beneficial to me than seeing people just snatch stuff down and just throwing it away without any thought of what it was worth.
This is the fourth house in a pilot project for New Orleans: a test of deconstruction as an alternative to demolition.
The Portland, Oregon-based relief organization Mercy Corps is paying for the deconstruction of 10 homes.
The project trains local demolition contractors how to forego wrecking balls and bulldozers and salvage up to two-thirds of the material in each house.
We're not just talking about carved mantles and crown molding.
Deconstruction digs deeper, says program officer and builder Rick Denhart, to harvest as much as possible from what amounts to an urban forest.
Six by sixes, two by sixes, two by fours.
You got doorjambs.
You got trim.
From this house Denhart estimates the salvaged material's total market value at up to $15,000.
The cost of deconstruction is $10,000.
The value of the material exceeds the cost of the deconstruction in something like this.
So when you're looking at a bottom line for what and how deconstruction compares to demolition, deconstruction will always come out ahead.
Post Katrina New Orleans seems like the place to test this approach on an unprecedented scale.
There are some 1700 homes on the city's condemned list.
But for most of them deconstruction is not a viable alternative.
The city's in a rush to demolish homes deemed an imminent health risk.

Today the House of Representatives approved legislation that gives the gun industry immunity from most liability lawsuits.

Passage of the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act gives the National Rifle Association and other gun groups their second major victory in Congress; the ban on assault weapons was allowed to expire last year.
The bill the House passed today has already cleared the Senate, so it goes right to President Bush.
As NPR's Larry Abramson reports, once the president signs the bill, it could quickly put an end to a number of lawsuits by cities and shooting victims.
Republicans were almost unanimously united behind this bill.
Cliff Stearns of Florida returned to an analogy that has become a classic in the debate over whether to allow lawsuits against the gun industry.
Would you hold a car company responsible if a driver gets drunk or reckless and hits somebody with a vehicle?
Of course not.
So, Stearns argued, gun makers and gun dealers should not be held liable if someone goes on a shooting spree with a weapon that was made and sold legally.
House Judiciary Committee Chair James Sensenbrenner said gun control advocates had only turned to lawsuits out of desperation.
